author: Jane Harper
title: Surf brand Quiksilver, led by former MFC captain Greg Healy, sinks into bankruptcy in US ahead of Oaktree Capital bailout deal
text:
SURF brand Quiksilver has sunk in the US under the pressure of fierce competition and a changing market and is expected to file for bankruptcy today.
The group, which was founded in the Victorian coastal town of Torquay in 1969, is believed to be filing for bankruptcy ahead of a potential bailout deal with US private equity firm Oaktree Capital Management.
The bankruptcy affects the only group’s operations in the US, where it is now based, with a listing on the New York Stock Exchange.
Quiksilver’s Australian and European operations will not be affected by the US collapse and will continue to run with business as usual. Both divisions are reportedly operating profitably.
In March, former Melbourne Football Club captain Greg Healy was appointed president of Quiksilver and tasked with leading a revival of the ailing brand in the US.
The deal with Oaktree is believed to include a $US175 million lifeline, which will see the private equity giant take control of the struggling company.
Oaktree played a major role in rescuing rival brand Billabong in 2013 after the group’s fortunes plunged on the back of weak sales and prolonged takeover tussles.
Oaktree’s managing director Matthew Wilson, yesterday stepped down from the Billabong board citing an unnamed conflict of interest.
California-based Quiksilver has struggled for several years as competition in the surf sector, changing fashion tastes and weak consumer sentiment hit sales.
Last year the chain suffered a 13 per cent drop in sales, and chalked up a net loss of $US309.4 million ($440 million).
